newsitem.title: USA: U.S. debt futures end higher after steadily rising.
newsitem.headline: U.S. debt futures end higher after steadily rising.

text.p: U.S. debt futures closed higher, but the market resorted to technical factors, rather than any fresh data or news, for its gains into the close, traders and analysts said.

The ability of June T-bonds to hold chart support at 108-30/32 at the opening attracted a consistent stream of retail buyers, they said. The 108-30/32 level roughly corresponded to a long bond yield of seven percent, some said.
"This was just the kind of market that day traders got chewed to bits," one bond futures analyst said. "They kept finding reasons for selling this market."
"Retail investors were lured into the market at the seven percent level," he said, referring to the 108-30/32 level.
Some traders also noted short-covering and fund buying, particularly in the note sector, for the market's steady march higher all day.
The U.S. weekly jobless claims, which rose higher than expected, coupled with the Federal Reserve's coupon pass, added to the constructive tone.
However, traders said shorts were established earlier in the day due to concerns about the dollar and the fate of the U.S. balanced-budget agreement.
Several traders also noted the rally in the Commodity Research Bureau Index led some pit and local traders to increase short positions.
"They really kept fighting the buying," another bond futures trader said.
Several bond futures sources said the gains could continue on Friday.
"I think enough weak longs liquidated during Wednesday's selloff," one bond trader said.
The next resistance level is at the 200-day moving average of 110-03/32.

At the end of pit trade, June T-bonds were up 16/32 at 109-26/32, 10-year notes were up 08/32 at 107-02/32, September T-bills were up 0.005 at 94.435, September Eurodollars were up 0.005 at 93.845, and December Eurodollars were 0.015 at 93.625. ((Derivatives desk 312-408-8750)
